title: Jeff Leal
text:
Jeff Leal (born December 13, 1954) is a former politician in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Canada. He was a <a href="Ontario%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> member of the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Ontario">Legislative Assembly of Ontario</a> from 2003 to 2018 who represented the riding of <a href="Peterborough%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">Peterborough</a>. He served in the cabinet of <a href="Kathleen%20Wynne">Kathleen Wynne</a>.
Background.
John Jeffrey Leal was born and raised in <a href="Peterborough%2C%20Ontario">Peterborough</a>. He attended <a href="Kenner%20Collegiate%20Vocational%20Institute">Kenner Collegiate</a> and has an Honours <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> degree in Economics and <a href="Political%20Science">Political Science</a> from <a href="Trent%20University">Trent University</a> (1978) and a degree in Business Administration from the <a href="University%20of%20Windsor">University of Windsor</a> (1981). Leal worked as executive assistant to <a href="Member%20of%20Provincial%20Parliament%20%28Ontario%29">Members of Provincial Parliament</a> (MPPs) <a href="John%20Eakins">John Eakins</a> and <a href="Larry%20South">Larry South</a> in the 1980s. He was a health and safety representative for Coyle Corrugated Containers. He is married to Karan, an educator and school principal, with two children, Braden and Shanae
Politics.
Municipal.
He served on the <a href="Peterborough%2C%20Ontario%20City%20Council">Peterborough, Ontario City Council</a> from 1985 to 2003, representing the Otonabee Ward. At City Hall he was appointed as Deputy Mayor (1993-2003) and chaired the social services committee after the 2000 municipal election.
Provincial.
Leal ran for provincial office in the <a href="1999%20Ontario%20general%20election">1999 provincial election</a> as the <a href="Ontario%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> candidate. He was narrowly defeated by <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Ontario">Progressive Conservative</a> incumbent <a href="Gary%20Stewart%20%28politician%29">Gary Stewart</a>. He defeated Stewart by over six thousand votes in a <a href="2003%20Ontario%20general%20election">2003</a> rematch, amid a provincial shift to the Liberal Party. Leal was re-elected in <a href="2007%20Ontario%20general%20election">2007</a>, <a href="2011%20Ontario%20general%20election">2011</a> and <a href="2014%20Ontario%20general%20election">2014</a>.
During his time in government he has served as <a href="Parliamentary%20Assistant">Parliamentary Assistant</a> to several ministers including <a href="Ministry%20of%20Training%2C%20Colleges%20and%20Universities%20%28Ontario%29">Ministry of Training, Colleges and Universities</a> (2004), <a href="Ministry%20of%20Economic%20Development%2C%20Trade%20and%20Employment%20%28Ontario%29">Ministry of Economic Development and Trade</a> (2005), <a href="Ministry%20of%20Energy%20%28Ontario%29">Ministry of Energy</a> (2005), <a href="Ministry%20of%20the%20Environment%20%28Ontario%29">Ministry of the Environment</a> (2006), and the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Aboriginal%20Affairs%20%28Ontario%29">Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs</a> (2007–09). In February 2010, he was named the <a href="Chief%20Government%20Whip%20%28Ontario%29">Chief Government Whip</a>.
In February 2013, Premier <a href="Kathleen%20Wynne">Kathleen Wynne</a> named Leal to <a href="Executive%20Council%20of%20Ontario">Ontario's Cabinet</a>, serving in the role as <a href="Ministry%20of%20Agriculture%2C%20Food%20and%20Rural%20Affairs%20%28Ontario%29">Minister of Rural Affairs</a>.
Leal has helped secure over $400 million in funding for <a href="Peterborough%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">Peterborough</a>, creating and preserving over 3,700 jobs with investments in infrastructure, transportation, businesses and health care. This included the creation of a new hospital, <a href="Peterborough%20Regional%20Health%20Centre">Peterborough Regional Health Centre</a>, and funding following a damaging flood in 2004.
Leal has championed a number of issues through private member's bills, including retirement and income security measures. He introduced a private member's bill in 2008 to provide creditor protection for <a href="Registered%20Retirement%20Savings%20Plan">Registered Retirement Savings Plan</a>s (RRSPs). Two years later, he introduced a separate bill that would require companies with twenty or more employees to offer a savings or pension plan that all employees would automatically join (with the ability to opt out). The stated purpose of this bill, which was supported by the <a href="Canadian%20Life%20and%20Health%20Insurance%20Association">Canadian Life and Health Insurance Association</a>, was to reduce the costs of such insurance plans compared with retail mutual funds.
In June 2014, Leal was appointed as the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Agriculture%2C%20Food%20and%20Rural%20Affairs%20%28Ontario%29">Minister of Agriculture and Food and Rural Affairs</a>.
